intro: Absinthium majus, commonly known as greater wormwood, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its tall, branched stems and narrow, gray-green leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in late summer. It is often found in dry, open habitats such as meadows and wastelands. Absinthium majus has been historically used in herbal medicine and is related to the plant used in the production of absinthe.
distribution_native_art_desc: Absinthium majus is primarily native to Central and Eastern Europe, including regions such as Poland, the Czech Republic, and parts of Russia. It is also found in the Balkans and extends into western Asia. This plant thrives in moist, calcareous soils and is commonly found in meadows, forest edges, and along riverbanks. It is a member of the Asteraceae family and is known for its aromatic foliage. Its distribution is closely tied to temperate climates with adequate moisture and sunlight.
